--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "nagendra.raja" <nagendra.raja@...> wrote:
Would it be possible to have Assert.fail(message, exception) method  in
future version of the junit. I see this to be very critical for methods
failing and resulting in exceptions. this way user could simultaneously
say what is related message resulting failure along with the exact stack
trace.
What would be the purpose? You get better information simply by letting
the original exception propagate. That is, by not intercepting it. If
the exception is a checked exception, simply add that exception type to
the test method's throws clause. In my opinion, more tests are crippled
by trying to catch exceptions and "re-throw" them with fail() than by
any other testing antipattern. The main, but not the only, legitimate
use of fail() is to cause test failure when you expected an exception to
be thrown but it was not. For example (JUnit 3):
public void testConnect_badURL() {
     try {
         service.setURL("https://bogus.site.danger.com");
         service.connect();

         fail("Should have thrown IOException");
     } catch (java.io.IOException ioe) {
         assertNotNull(ioe);
         assertEquals("Unable to connect: https://bogus.site.danger.com",
             ioe.getMessage());
     }
}
In the case where you are using what you expect is a good URL and it
still throws the bad URL exception, you should, instead 0f catching the
exception and manufacturing a failure, just let it pass through and
cause an error. For example:
public void testConnect_goodURL() throws java.io.IOException {
     service.setURL("https://perfectly.legitimate.serviceURL.com");
     HttpsURLConnection connection = (HttpsURLConnection)
service.connect();
     assertNotNull(connection);
}If the connect() method throws an exception here, this code gives you
exactly what you are looking for, full exception message and stack trace
data, without resorting to try-catch and fail().
Also, junit does not give the count of no of test cases passed.. it says
total, failed and errors only.. would be happy to see total passed and
its % to encourage people to work on fixing others.

Another need, which I had been badly looking for was no of asserts which
have been executed.. this tells me how much of auto testing has been
done.

i.e assertEquals() assertNotNull all these calls should have a way
report to total assertcounter.
I have no opinion on any of these. I don't need them, but I can
understand why someone else might want them.
